G.L. c. 208 (allocation of parental resp.raw_text: G.L. c. 208 (allocation of parental responsibility and divorce-related custody)
G.L. c. 208 (allocation of parental resp.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over custody and visitation matters and modification of custody orders under Massachusetts law, including G.L. c. 208 (allocation of parental responsibility and divorce-related custody), and the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act, G.L. c. 209D.

G.L. c. 209D..proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over custody and visitation matters and modification of custody orders under Massachusetts law, including G.L. c. 208 (allocation of parental responsibility and divorce-related custody), and the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act, G.L. c. 209D.

G.L. c. 208 (statutory authority for cus.raw_text: G.L. c. 208 (statutory authority for custody orders and modifications)
G.L. c. 208 (statutory authority for cus.proposition: See generally G.L. c. 208 (statutory authority for custody orders and modifications); G.L. c. 209D (UCCJEA) (jurisdictional provisions); accord Massachusetts cases applying the material-change/best-interest standard.

G.L. c. 209D (UCCJEA) (jurisdictional pr.proposition: See generally G.L. c. 208 (statutory authority for custody orders and modifications); G.L. c. 209D (UCCJEA) (jurisdictional provisions); accord Massachusetts cases applying the material-change/best-interest standard.

G.L. c. 208 (Custody provisions).proposition: Relevant authorities include, by way of example and illustration: G.L. c. 208 (Custody provisions); G.L. c. 209D (UCCJEA); G.L. c. 119 (child welfare); and controlling Massachusetts precedent establishing that modification requires both a material change and a best-interests analysis.

G.L. c. 209D (UCCJEA).proposition: Relevant authorities include, by way of example and illustration: G.L. c. 208 (Custody provisions); G.L. c. 209D (UCCJEA); G.L. c. 119 (child welfare); and controlling Massachusetts precedent establishing that modification requires both a material change and a best-interests analysis.

G.L. c. 119 (child welfare).proposition: Relevant authorities include, by way of example and illustration: G.L. c. 208 (Custody provisions); G.L. c. 209D (UCCJEA); G.L. c. 119 (child welfare); and controlling Massachusetts precedent establishing that modification requires both a material change and a best-interests analysis.
